entry.title: On tech for tech’s sake
entry.content:
You may well know that I have a newsletter.

My reasoning was simple: I spend a lot of my time reading tech news, so why not share my thoughts on it? I already use Readwise (RIP Omnivore) to make notes on things I read, so surely it would only be a little effort to turn that into useful content for others.

Having had the thought, some hours later I had the perfect system. Using an automation platform and the OpenAI API, I had a completely automated workflow that, once a week, took all my notes from tech articles I’d read in the past 7 days, structured them into an email, generated an intro and outro for the whole thing, and then sent that to me so that it could make final edits before sending it to my adoring fans.

There was just one problem.

It sucked.

The system itself worked flawlessly. And if I’d wanted an AI generated round-up of the things I’d read that week, this would have been fine. Perfect, in fact. But I used the system for about a month, and there wasn’t a single thing the AI wrote for me that I didn’t rewrite into my own words.

Yes, I could refine the AI Assistant, feed it examples of my writing, and make it better at mimicing me. But the thing is, I like writing the newsletter. What’s more, I don’t want people to read AI-generated thoughts on articles that apparently have a 50/50 shot of being, themselves, AI-generated.

There wasn’t a single thing the AI wrote that I didn’t end up rewriting.

When you take that bit out, all the automation is really doing is sending the content through half a dozen different systems to wrangle it into a format that will play nice with the next system in the chain. Aside from that not really making sense, it’s terrible practice. If any one of those services changes the way they work, it could break my entire flow.

Here’s what I do now:

Notice anything? It’s basically the exact same thing I was doing, without the automation block. I’m doing, essentially, exactly the same amount of work with or without the automation.

The human desire to over-use technology

Don’t get me wrong. There are plenty of things that automation is good for. And being able to use ChatGPT and others to assist with some of life’s more mundane office tasks is great.

But just because these technologies exist, it doesn’t mean we have to use them. For me and my newsletter, there isn’t really any benefit for me in overengineering a solution. Cramming new and shiny technology into places where there is no need for it just doesn’t make sense. And that’s before you start to think about the moral and ethical implications of some of the technology we use.

There’s often a real fear that if we aren’t at least dabbling the latest and greatest, we’ll fall behind to the point of obselecence. So let me be one voice on the other side of that argument. It’s ok to not always be at the bleeding edge.

I’m not saying stick your head in the sand - there’s a balance. Be aware of the landscape and what’s going on, and then judge for yourselves (with some professional help if needed…) what the right tools for the job are.

But if you’re looking at a new tool that someone is selling you, and you can’t figure out where it makes sense to put it in your organisation, there’s a good chance that’s because it doesn’t fit. And that’s ok.

entry.title: Getting hacked - its not “if”, it’s “when”
entry.content:
I spend much of my professional time reminding people of the importance of good cyber security. This week, that lesson hit home for me, as my LinkedIn profile was hacked. For about 48 hours someone else had complete control over my account.

And they really did a number on me. For starters, they changed my password and changed the two-step verification to make sure I couldn’t get back in. They also changed my name and profile picture, replaced all my education and work experience, and deleted all my recent activity to replace it with their own.

It could have been worse. I eventually got it back (by filling out LinkedIn’s Report Unauthorized Access form). In any case, there are limited (though not zero) things you can do with access to my LinkedIn account. The whole experience did serve as a reminder that, even if you’re constantly preaching the good cyber security word, no one is immune from being compromised.

It’s not a case of “if” you get hacked, but “when”.

I’m still looking in to how it happened, but it could have been a number of different things. My current working theory is that I fell foul of any one of a number of recent password leaks. Or maybe it isn’t as complicated as that. LinkedIn is not exactly known for being Fort Knox. This blog post from LinkedIn user Nazmul Ahsan, describes how all it took to lose his account was for someone to contact customer service and pretend to be him.

But why would anyone bother? I’m not particularly active on LinkedIn, and there isn’t much data held privately that you can’t see on my public profile. What benefit does someone get by stealing my account?

Well, in 2024 it’s getting increasingly harder to scam people. As viewers of Netflix’s Sweet Bobby will know, one of the things that makes a lie believable is accompanying evidence. Creating a series of fake social media accounts is easy. Creating believable social media accounts, with hundreds of connections to other people? Well, that’s a little more complicated. It’s far easier to just steal an existing account, wipe the recent history, and replace it with your own content. I suspect that, if I’d let the perpetrator carry on, they would have used it as a base from which to scam other people.

Everyone is a target, even if you’re not the target.

How can you protect yourself against hackers?

I’ve already said that being hacked is inevitable, and I stand by that. But that doesn’t mean you shouldn’t still put up a good fight. What can you do to make it as hard as possible for people to get access to your data?

Good password hygiene is crucial.

This section should be teaching you to suck eggs. But I would be remiss as a technology professional if I didn’t put it here, so let’s just dive in.

Make your passwords long and complicated.

A simple piece of advice for a simple reason. Regardless of whether a human or a machine is trying to guess your password, the longer and more complicated it is, the harder it will be to guess. Adding symbols, numbers, and a mixture of upper and lower case letters all add to the complexity.

Hard to guess doesn’t have to be hard to remember. BeCyberSafe.com have an excellent article for 12 Strong Password Ideas, one of which is using a sentence as your password. For example, rather than putting your cat’s name followed by “1234”, you might have a password like “MittensReallyLikesHer3SquareMealsADay!”. It includes the usually compulsory mixture of cases, numbers, and special characters, while also being long and hard to guess.

Don’t use the same password for multiple accounts.

If I used the same password for LinkedIn as, say, for my email account, then anyone gaining access to one also gets the other. If you control my email account, you have a much stronger chance of being able to gain access to pretty much any online service I have - including the big scary ones like online banking, government portals, etc.

By making sure that every single account I have uses a different password, I limit my exposure if one of those accounts is compromised.

Change your password frequently.

This advice is not as universal as the others. In fact, even the National Cyber Security Centre recommends not forcing users to frequently change passwords. There is good reason for that. If you’re asking people to change their passwords every 3 months, eventually they are going to get bored of thinking up new complex passwords. Instead, they’ll settle for the old “stick an exclamation mark at the end of the last password” method. This is a slippery slope to weaker and weaker passwords, until you’re all but forced by your brain to just use the same simple password for everything, because you can’t think of your 43rd new password of the year for yet another platform.

On the flipside, if your data gets leaked, by changing your passwords frequently you limit the amount of time between your password being available and it being useful. Legally, organisations who know of a data leak should report this to users as soon as possible. So you could just keep an eye out… on every communication channel… for every online service you use… assuming that every platform knows the second they are breached… and are definitely not slow to let everyone know about it…

All I’m saying is that while I agree with the NCSC that forcing people to change their passwords frequently can lead to lazy passwords, it can give an extra layer of protection. But only if your passwords are good. And to make sure you hit all of these criteria, we move onto the next tool in your arsenal…

If all this sounds like a lot, have you considered a password manager?

I literally can’t count the number of online services I use. The idea that I could come up with a complex, unique password for each of those, and change it even once a year (let alone every 3 months), is madness. So I don’t bother with any of that.

Instead, I use a password manager. There are loads of options: LastPass, Bitwarden, 1Password, Proton Pass, to name just 4 off the top of my head. Each has their own set of pros and cons, their own price points, and their own loyal user bases. Which one is right for you will depend, but look out for some basic protections like strong encryption, secure password generators, and helpful bonuses like dark web scanning.

Need help finding the right password manager for you? Let’s have a chat!

“But Will? What if the Password Manager gets hacked?” I hear you ask. What a fantastic question. And it does happen. A couple of years ago LastPass - a service I often recommended - suffered a major data breach. This is where ensuring your password manager has strong encryption comes in. In the LastPass case, hackers gained access to a bunch of passwords, but they couldn’t read them without breaking the encryption. This is technically possible, but extremely hard to do.

But nothing is flawless, and that’s why you need one more string to your cyber security bow…

Don’t just rely on your password.

Use Multifactor Authentication wherever possible. Sometimes called 2-Factor Authentication, or Two Step Verification, this is exactly what it sounds like. Your password is not the only thing the platform will ask you for to ensure you are the owner of the account.

Most major platforms will allow you to do this now, and some (including most banks) in fact demand it. It is annoying, I know. It’s annoying to setup. And it’s annoying having to dig out your phone every time you want to check your Bluesky feed on your laptop. But take it from me, having to spend the day undoing a bunch of changes to your compromised LinkedIn account - including adding back in nearly 20 years of deleted work experience - is considerably more annoying.

Final thoughts…

You might be thinking that, as a technology consultant (and general IT-know-it-all), I would be pretty embarrassed that I lost control of my LinkedIn account for two days.

But the truth is I’m not.

Everyone, at some point in their online journey, is going to experience a cyber security mishap. Maybe it will be a dodgy email you don’t quite read properly, a link you don’t double check. Perhaps, you really needed to send a work email and the only option was public WiFi. Or, maybe you did everything right, and an online service suffers a data breach.

Whatever the reason, if it hasn’t happened to you yet, it will. Don’t panic, and don’t be ashamed. Just don’t make it too easy.

entry.title: Free and Open Source Software - a crash course

link.title: Free and Open Source Software - a crash course

entry.content:
Intro - what is FOSS?

Free and Open Source Software (FOSS). You may have come across the term before, but what does it mean? Well, the “free” bit is fairly straightforward - free software is software that you don’t have to pay for.

But what about the “Open Source” part? Well, Open Source software means that the code that makes up the software has been published online, and is available for anyone to review and even to adapt and change for their own purposes.

How noble… what’s the catch?

You’re right to be skeptical in these trying times. We all know there is no such thing as a free lunch. Why would people go to the effort of making entire applications, and then just give them away?

There are actually a number of reasons. One possibility, is that people are using it to showcase their talents, with the view to generating interest in other things they want to sell. Perhaps offering a completely free Chrome extension, that links back to the portfolio website they use to generate business.

Others make money not from the software itself, which they give away freely, but from selling service packages to help you install and manage the product.

Still others just want to solve a personal issue that’s been bugging them. Perhaps they need a way to put a customisable blog online. Having solved the problem, they put the code online and soon others are contributing, adding their own ideas. Before you know it, there’s a whole community around the software, and it’s the most popular free CMS platform on the planet.

Finally, there is a subset of FOSS that is perhaps much more recognisable to the capitalist world. Companies - yes companies - like Oracle or the Mozilla Foundation create lots of software in the way a “normal” software company does, but they are funded by grants or other charitable activities. The software they give away is as professional, secure, and feature rich as anything else, but they do not operate for a profit.

Regardless of the origins of your FOSS, there are some things to consider. We’ll come back to those at the end, but for now let’s explore what your FOSS options are. This is by no means an extensive list - something like that would be nearly impossible to collate. Instead, this is a list of the tools I think are the best fit for small organisations with limited budget and IT capacity. They straddle the line between functionality, ease of use, and (obviously) price. If you’re looking to dip your toes in the waters of FOSS, then this list might just help you out.

You can also get your FOSS fix by heading to the Resource Centre.

Let’s get our FOSS on…

Want to ditch Microsoft Office? Try LibreOffice.

Perhaps the first question on your mind if you’re thinking about switching software is “how will I type my documents?”. Well, ask any nerd IT professional, and their first answer is likely to be LibreOffice. A veritable crown-jewel in the FOSS pantheon.

I say “crown-jewel”… Look, I’ll say it right off the bat. For those used to the hyper polished look of Microsoft or Apple products, you might not think this the prettiest software on the list. Don’t let that fool you though, what it lacks in sleekness, it makes up for in functionality. And, you know, being completely free. You’ll get more or less everything you’ll need from an Office suite - with Writer, Calc, and Impress ready to take the reins from Word, Excel, and PowerPoint respectively.

Will this give you everything that Microsoft Word will? Unfortunately not. One of the major benefits of the Microsoft 365 architecture is the ability to near-seamlessly document share and collaborate. Whether that’s through SharePoint, via Teams, or even directly sharing a document and having a colleague work with you in real time. These things are not available to LibreOffice users.

It is also worth noting that, while LibreOffice can open and read, for example, Word documents, sometimes the formatting is specific to the Microsoft-owned .docx file type, and so you may experience some weird text placements moving from one software to another.

But, if those things aren’t deal breakers for you, then you can pick yourself up an established, supported, and robust Office Suite for the princely sum of £0. And hey, if it works for city councils ranging from Limerick to Barcelona, then it’s probably worth some thought?

Editing images? Check out GIMP.

The GNU Image Manipulation Programme is a… well it’s a programme that allows you to manipulate images… Whether you want to touch up some holiday photos, or create your own artwork from scratch, GIMP might well be the only tool you need.

As a Photoshop replacement, it gets you most of the way there. What you can’t do out of the box, you might be able to find in the form of extensions, or in presets that other users have uploaded.

GNU, incidentally, is a collection of free software that can come together as a whole Operating System, or be used as parts within other Operating Systems. It stands for “GNU is not Unix”, for nerd reasons.

Need to edit video content? Use Shotcut

You can’t search for “free video editor” without coming across Blender, one of the darlings of the FOSS ecosystem. A fully fledged graphics tool that can do everything from edit your videos to create and render 3D animation. It’s a fantastic product, but comes with a huge learning curve.

Less well known, but my personal go-to, is Shotcut. If all you need is a tool to edit some videos - perhaps for creating online content - I highly recommend checking this out. It’s simple to use, but comes with some powerful features. It’s my go to software for editing HowTo videos before I send them to clients, including things like adding preset title cards, captions, and all the usual transitions (who doesn’t love a good star-wipe?).

Bonus video related software: If you want to capture video - maybe record your screen for a tutorial video, or stream your gaming session for your Twitch followers, then have a look at OBS.

In need of a FOSS web browser? I use Firefox

Statistically speaking, you’re reading this from a Chrome browser. For a long while now, Chrome has ruled the roost in the “things I access the internet with”. Recently though, I made the switch from Chrome to Firefox. Why? Well I actually wrote a whole blog post about it. But in typical fashion, that whole post can probably be summed up in two bullet points:

  • Chrome was taking up a lot of resources, noticeably slowing down my laptop

  • I wanted to move away from Google and put my support into something Free and Open Source

Firefox is where I landed. Philosophically, I like what the Mozilla Foundation are doing, and - as importantly - Firefox is a great browser. If you’ve been on Chrome for any length of time, you’ll likely have a number of extensions that you don’t want to lose. The good news is that a lot of the better-known extensions exist on both browsers. You can also import all your history and bookmarks over as well, should you feel the need.

Bonus Mozilla tip: If you’re in the market for an email client (maybe new Outlook is causing you grief) you should check out Thunderbird, also from Mozilla. There are some caveats if you still have a Microsoft 365 email, but if you’re on Google or another client, then it’s a very good option.

Some other things to consider

When you get a Microsoft 365 environment, or you setup a Google Workspace for your company, it’s not just the access to applications you’re getting. For most of those, there are FOSS alternatives.

But you’re also getting things like cloud storage, some form of cyber protection, and, if you’re in charge of multiple users, the ability to centrally manage your infrastructure. On top of all that, you’re also getting access to email, alternatives for which we haven’t covered here (watch this space).

If none of those things are super important to you - maybe you’re a one-person setup, or a very small team that doesn’t need a central file share - then some of these options will genuinely give you everything you need.

Equally, if you are a larger organisation - perhaps a school or research institution - you can get some SLA (Service Level Agreements) on tools like LibreOffice. You still don’t pay anything for the software, but you pay for support and service management. For many, this is a good middle ground.

But jumping wholesale into the FOSS ecosystem isn’t for everybody - and that’s ok! The great news is that it’s not an all-or-nothing option. Just because you need to stick with Microsoft for your email and office suite, doesn’t mean you can’t check out Shortcut for your video editing, or GIMP for your images.

Free and Open Source Software is built on the philosophy that good quality software should be accessible to everyone. If that’s something you think you can get on board with, then why not explore some of those options today?
