entry.title: RSS: Why I think it’s overdue a comeback

link.title: RSS: Why I think it’s overdue a comeback

entry.content:
I’ve been thinking a lot about RSS lately. I know, I know. My last post was about the emerging super-tech that is generative AI. And here I am thinking about technology that predates the original iPad. By a decade. But you heard it here first: RSS is making a comeback! We’re hearing more and more about ChatGPT, Co-Pilot, Gemini, and the others. But I’ve also been hearing more and more people talk about RSS. Even the guys over on the Hard Fork podcast have been chatting about it.

For me, the two things are related - the more we’re talking about the new and shiny AI tools, the more we’re also talking about some of the early building blocks of the web.

So, what is RSS? Where did it go? And why is it coming back? Well friends, grab yourself a cup of tea and settle in…

What is RSS: a quick intro

RSS (“really simple syndication”) is a text-based, machine-readable, web feed. It’s essentially a way of tracking when a particular source has posted something new. In the early days of the internet, the World Wide Web was just that - a web of barely connected websites, from blogs, forums, news pages, webcomics, you name it. And if you wanted to keep up to date on everything, you needed to visit each of those places individually to find out what was happening. You “surfed the web”, if you will.

You used to have to “surf the web” because there was no easy way to bring together the things you wanted to see.

Then, in 1999, RSS came along. It gave us a way for websites to let users know when there was an update. Instead of going to your favourite blogger’s website every morning when you got to work and keeping your fingers crossed, you’d fire up your RSS Reader and get a list of the latest from across your web.

This was a game-changer. With an RSS Reader, you could amalgamate everything you wanted to check out from different pockets of the internet. If that sounds like a familiar concept to you, that’s because the way we use the web hasn’t really changed since then. The main difference is that today, instead of RSS feeds, we use social media. One social media platform above others has taken on the mantle of spiritual successor to our good friend RSS: Twitter.

Where did RSS go?

While Twitter was never the most popular social media platform by number of users - that honour goes to Facebook - it had something none of the others had. The brevity of posts, the ability to follow anyone, and the vast mix of noraml people, celebrities, organisations, and news outlets, meant it really was the only place you needed if you wanted to curate your sources of knowledge. People who had blogs would let their Twitter followers know when they posted. News outlets would post breaking stories on Twitter. Pop stars would annouce their latest albums. If you wanted to update the wider world about something, you headed over to let that little blue bird know.

It had the upsides of RSS - ease of use, and all your favourite things in one place. But it also had RSS beat in one very big way. RSS is a one-way street. Twitter gave you the ability to talk back. To anybody. About anything. Communication was never the same again.

The late 2000s / early 2010s saw a steady decline in RSS. In 2013, Google shutdown it’s RSS Reader, signaling to many that the age of RSS had officially ended. The technology still lived on, of course. In fact, even today if you subscribe to any podcasts, it’s RSS that lets your app know when a new episode is live. And most publications and blogs still have RSS feeds built into them - apps like Feedly and Omnivore will make use of them for you. But it’s no longer part of the mainstream vernacular of the internet.

I think that might change.

What might cause the renaiRSSance

Alright, that one was a stretch…

For all its lack of two-way communication, or fancy hashtagging, you know one thing RSS never did? It never showed you anything you hadn’t subscribed to. As social media platforms needed to capture more users and drive more traffic, they implemented algorithms. These bits of code learned what you shared, made notes of what the people you followed liked, and ultimately started to change what you saw on your feed. Platforms included adverts and promoted posts. They showed you things that people outside your internet circle thought were popular. As time went on, less and less of your feed was things that you had originally signed up to follow.

For some people in some contexts, this is fine. Better than fine in fact. TikTok pretty much operates on the basis that its users want to see new, popular, trending things, regardless of who it’s from. In other corners of the internet though, this isn’t what people signed up for. Elon Musk was the final straw for Twitter, but usage was declining long before that.

People are still consuming content at increasing rates though. By the time NPR left X, the news outlet reported a negligible decline in visitors to their site. It didn’t matter that they’d gone, because people had already been getting their NPR updates from another medium. A large part of their traffic had long been coming from - you guessed it! RS- nah I’m kidding. It was newsletters.

Newsletters, in fact, have been doing remarkably well. Back in 2022, Reuters reported that 70% of the publishers they surveyed were putting more resources into newsletters than other platforms. They were betting big on email, and pulling funding from “traditional” social media. Why is that, I wonder? What is it about subscribing to a specific publication, and getting the updates from that publication all in one place, that you can peruse at your leisure?

So newsletters are the way forward, not RSS?

Maybe. But I think newsletters are only a small part of the puzzle.

People want more control over the content they consume. Newsletters give that, but there are still hurdles. From the content creator side, there’s no shortage of platforms you can use to run a newsletter business. But as with many things tech, these platforms themselves come under scrutiny. Substack, perhaps the best-known platform, hit the headlines late last year for all the wrong reasons when it refused to take down the newsletters of actual neo-Nazis. They later backtracked (sort of…), but the whole affair caused a lot of discussion in the space about where content creators should go to host their content. What was wrong, some asked, with the good old-fashioned website?

We want more control over the content we consume. Social media isn’t giving us that.

I also think there is a space for content consumption outside of our email inboxes. I’ve talked before about how I use Omnivore and RSS to get my news. I’m a nerd, and not representative of the population at large. However, I think there is something to be said for a completely curated feed, free of algorithmic influence, and separate from the systems we have to use for work. For about 5 minutes, I thought Mastodon might be the answer. But the social media landscape is now far too fragmented. Between Mastodon, and BlueSky, and Threads, and X, and the half dozen others that will have popped up in the time it’s taken me to write this post, it’s just not a streamlined way for someone producing content to reach a wide audience.

So, I’m setting my stall out. I think we’ll see the comeback of RSS. It’s not the solution we deserve, but it’s the one we need right now.

Oh, and if you want the RSS feed for this blog, you can point your readers to: https://willrc.co.uk/feed/

entry.title: Some thoughts on AI
entry.content:
ChatGPT has been around for a little while. Lately though, we’ve had some other big players join the “Generative AI” arena. Perhaps most notable is Microsoft making their Copilot considerably easier to access. For about £25 a month, you get Microsoft’s range of AI tools.

So, what does this mean for the current state of play for Generative Artificial Intelligence? Who is using it, and what are they using it for? Perhaps most importantly, is it worth getting?

Let’s find out.

What are we using AI for?

In a survey of over 140 IT Leaders, The Channel Company (parent company for, among other publications, Computing.com) found that 76% of respondents use AI for Data Analytics. Additionally, 60% said they used AI Assistants, and 40% used AI for Natural Language Processing.

What is interesting to me is that none of these things are groundbreaking. We’ve had Machine Learning helping us with data analysis for decades, and AI Assistants have been accessible to the masses in various forms since the first iPhone. Don’t get me wrong. The quality of the work from today’s AI is streets ahead of where it used to be. The idea that 2011 Siri would do anything useful is laughable. But sci-fi of old promised us a redefined society: a flying-car filled utopia. When are we getting that?

What we’re using AI for isn’t groundbreaking - but it’s reach is about to be.

We’re a little way off yet. But what is happening is still hugely beneficial, and we’re only just figuring out how the “average” person can use it.

Let’s look at Microsoft Copilot again. One of the things it advertises is a better way to attend meetings. You can join a Teams call with your colleagues and have Copilot “sit in” taking notes. At the end of the meeting, you’ll almost instantly have a transcript of what was said by whom. But no one’s got time to read a transcript to understand what went on, so you’ll also get a summary, distilled into 5 or 6 bullet points, as well as any action points from the meeting. That’s easily an hour of someone’s time post-meeting that they can get back.

What else? Let’s say you’ve got to run through the results of a 300-person survey. You’ve got to collate all that data, put it into a two-page report for your Senior Management Team, and you also need to produce a 5-slide presentation to give at the next all-hands meeting. How long are you going to block out to do that? A couple of hours? Half a day? A full day? Seems long. And besides, no one has a full day to put aside for this kind of work, so you’re going to have to split that time out across three weeks’ worth of 2 hours here and 40 minutes there. It’s going be draining having to switch back and forth, and it’ll likely push back other timelines that you’re working on.

That seems like a waste of everyone’s time. Now, you can get Copilot to do all that in a matter of minutes, and you only spend half an hour checking it over and making some light edits.

This sort of thing is going to become really popular, really quickly. A lot of people already have a Microsoft 365 license, so adding this feature on for - as all the marketing will remind you - about £1 a day seems like a no-brainer. It’s also a much simpler sell for companies compared to, for example, ChatGPT. Copilot is ChatGPT with bells on, but those bells integrate it directly with your email, your calendar, with PowerPoint, with…

Because of the price point, companies will quickly see a return on spending. It’s hard to get figures on exactly what this looks like. But even if Microsoft’s claim that you can “clear your inbox in minutes, not hours” is the only thing the tool does, and you spend two hours a day on emails, then suddenly £25 buys me nearly 3 days a month back. And that’s without the other bells and whistles Microsoft tells me Copilot can do. With that time, I can start to work on more strategic work.

To work that out, I assumed that Copilot could cut down my emailing from 2 hours to 1 hour a day. I assumed a 5-day working week, meaning 5 hours saved over a week. With an average of 4 weeks in a month, that’s 20 hours saved. If a work day lasts 8 hours, then overall I get 2.5 days back just by saving 1 hour a day of email time.

But will AI take my job?

Am I worried about jobs? Only a little. As someone who has been a web developer for the last decade and a half, I liken the rise in Generative AI to the popularity of platforms like Squarespace.

Squarespace leveled the playing field when it came to building websites. It’s a great piece of kit for anyone who wants to build a small portfolio website, a blog, a modest online store, etc. If you want a site, you want it done, and you want as little fuss as possible - have at it. Spend a couple of hours getting the look right - you don’t need to spin up servers, you don’t need to configure WordPress or install plugins. £10/month, job done. It’s fantastic - and I say that as someone who makes money doing the same thing that you can pay Squarespace to do.

Except I don’t - and that’s the point. Squarespace isn’t going to help you if you need a completely stand-out website. It’s not the right tool for you if you want a bespoke CMS for your publication. It’s going to struggle if you need a high-traffic, multi-seller, international e-commerce platform. You can’t use it if you have specific data security requirements. Squarespace isn’t designed to help in those cases. In those scenarios, and hundreds more, you need a web developer. (Hello, by the way! 👋)

Generative AI is like Squarespace - a great tool for a simple and specific need.

I don’t believe I’ve lost significant business because Squarespace exists. I also think that thousands more people have an accessible online voice because of the likes of Squarespace, people who wouldn’t have been able to have one without it.

In the same vein, I don’t believe this wave of AI will result in millions of 9-5 “office worker” jobs lost. There are things it just isn’t designed to do. There was a period where we all got caught up in the hype that AI would solve everything, and we’d be able to kick back in our utopia while the robots did all the work. Maybe that’s coming, but not yet. Not soon. And that’s OK - technology isn’t really supposed to be a broad-brush solution to all problems. Specific interventions need to be specifically deployed to get the best out of it. That’s where I believe we’re at. We are going to see an exponential rise in the number of people using Generative AI, in a much smaller number of use cases.

I think that’s going to be really exciting. The low-hanging fruit, the easy return on investment stuff, will be more widely used. It’s will really open up how people can spend their time - not just physical hours, but also the mental capacity to think about more important things.

Final thoughts

It’s quite the rosy picture I’ve painted! Don’t misunderstand me, I know there are still hurdles to jump. There are ethical considerations, climate change factors, and myriad data concerns surrounding AI that I’ve not explored here. In the coming weeks and months, I will break these down. Watch this space.

I also know that there are likely to be cases of some jobs being replaced, despite my sunny optimism. But in the round, I think we’re less likely to see entire jobs being taken over by machines, and instead have individual people be “augmented” in specific ways, giving them back time and capacity.

I work predominately in the charity and social sector. It’s a space where it’s common for any given person to be doing the work of four people. I’m excited for a world where it’s accessible - both in terms of price and ease of use - for people in the space to only do the work of three people. Maybe even only two.

I jest (sort of). But it is a real possibility. Small organisations can’t afford to hire extra people, and AI isn’t able to replace existing ones. But, perhaps for the first time, we have a genuinely viable third option, where for a little extra money we might get a lot more out. It will help people redefine what their work is, and to spend their time doing more meaningful work.

So that’s where I think we are. And I am excited.

entry.title: I’ve recently changed how I consume content

link.title: I’ve recently changed how I consume content

entry.content:
I’ve been doing a revamp of the way I consume data lately, and in the interest of sharing (and having more content to write) I thought I’d post it here.

This also coincided with me getting a new phone, and not reinstalling many of my ‘usual’ social media apps. I’ve realised how much of my time I spent on X - not just doom-scrolling (though there was plenty of that), but also as a source of news, and sometimes a place to store thoughts.

Anyway, here’s how I digitally organise my brain. Shout out to the two big apps in my life: Omnivore, and Obsidian. They feature a lot in this post.

Technology exists to make things easier. If it isn’t doing that, then rethink what you’re using it for.

The Funnel - where I get my content

Mastodon

Since I don’t really use Twitter/X anymore, I’ve joined the pilgrimage to Mastodon. I think I’m still a little way off where I was at peak Twitter, but that is mostly because I’m trying to compare 10 years of Twitter use with like 10 months on the Fediverse. That said I do get a good amount of use from it - particularly accounts like Longreads or more tech-specific feeds.

I’ve talked a little before about the way that Mastodon differs from Twitter, but one of the benefits, for me at least, is that it I’ve found it very easy to curate a feed that is predominantly about technology. I struggle to remember what the early days of Twitter were like. But even before it devolved it was still quite a “broad” place. Good, in its own way, but perhaps less focused.

RSS feeds and Omnivore

I’ve had a tumultuous relationship with RSS over the years. Like many, for the last decade I lamented the loss of Google Reader. In it’s wake, I’ve tried a lot of options, from Feedly to Flipboard. But for some reason they’ve never really stuck. I think because I would use the RSS reader as the place to read content, and then have a different app to make notes, and then a different one again to store things like highlights / favourite posts etc.

Enter Omnivore - for me it’s the first actual “most in one” platform that I’ve used where I actually do the things it suggests in the platform. You can subscribe to RSS feeds and the platform will periodically pull those feeds into your inbox, sync them for offline viewing (if you’re on mobile), and also allow you to make highlights and annotations. You can also create email addresses to allow you to sign up to newsletters, and read those in the app, keeping your inbox free of that ever expanding filtered folder of unread emails.

But neither of those were what initially drew me to Omnivore. It was actually it’s function as a “read it later” platform that swung it for me. It’s clean, has the usual tagging functionality you’d expect, and even lets you highlight and annotate pages from the app. Most importantly for me though, the mobile app is fantastic, and the ability to sync and read longform content offline has been a game changer. Despite living in 2023, I still find myself in patches of no signal for considerable stretches of my commute. Omnivore makes it really easy to scroll the usual places for things to read, send them over to the platform, and then actually do the reading while I’ve got no signal.

It will also allow you to spit things out into other applications, which for me is great because of the next part of my thought pipeline…

The hub - where it all lives

Obsidian

I’ve been back and forth with Obsidian for a while. A mixture of not really having the rest of my pipeline sorted, and being entrenched in Notion for so long, meant that despite conceptually loving it, Obsidian never really stuck for me.

Meanwhile I loved Notion. It works like my brain works, and it can be adapted to handle pretty much anything. You need a basic project management tool? Somewhere to send articles to read and annotate later? A place to track habits? Somewhere to draft blog posts? Notion can handle all of that easily.

But lately it’s been running really slowly for me - something that is a common criticism of the platform. For me also, I need it to work smoothly offline, and Notion just doesn’t. I find myself doing a lot of note-taking and reading on my phone. Notion, for all its many many perks, does not behave well for me when all I want to do is fire up an app and jot down some thoughts.

Meanwhile, Obsidian is an offline product. It offers the same experience across platforms - handy for someone who spends an equal amount of time across Windows, Linux, and Android. It also has a number of options for dealing with syncing across devices. I’ve opted to pay for Obsidian’s own sync function (about £80 for the year), but there are other community driven ways of dealing with this.

Speaking of the community, there are thousands of extensions you can download and use to enhance Obsidian. It takes the opposite approach to tools like Notion, and gives you a streamlined base that you can customise exactly how you want, rather than giving you the world and letting you decide which corners you want to live in.

Neither option is inherently better or worse. The fact that everything is immediately available to you in Notion in some ways makes it easier to discover what it can do. But part of my issue with it has been it’s speed, and it’s hard to look past that.

What I’ve learned

Being offline is more important to me than I realised

I should have known this, having oft lamented the old-school Chromebooks with their very generous definition of working online. (Reader: they don’t.)

I’m not one to claim that I want to optimise every second of my day. But equally I have really noticed how much more on the ball with specific topics I’ve been since reworking my pipeline. I can use the time on my commute to read and reflect on things that are important to me, rather than just scrolling aimlessly through my socials.

It goes beyond just using my commute time better. There’s much less friction between me having a thought and writing it down - and specifically between me reading something and having a thought about it, and then writing that down. Omnivore even syncs my Kindle highlights for me, so I’m not confined to just ruminating on news stories.

Simpler is better, but it’s also subjective

I didn’t intend for this to be an advert for Omnivore and Obsidian, and these platforms definitely won’t be for everyone. But one of the main draws for me is Obsidian’s use of Markdown. As I’ve mentioned before, I really like the format for writing, but might not be everyone’s cup of tea. That Markdown-first way of capturing content, combined with a flexible way of storing, sorting, and linking data, makes it really easy for me to use Obsidian as my complete personal library.

Final Thoughts

In reality, I probably count have replaced all of the above with the following three takeaways:

  1. Being more selective about the social media you consume makes it easier to give yourself the brain space to actually consume and reflect on it. Go figure…

  2. Technology isn’t always about fancy plugins and shiny features. Sometimes the best tech just gets out of your way and lets you do the thinking.

  3. It feels like we’re constantly pushed towards cloud-based and online options for products - in part because it’s easier there to push the shiny new things that keep you interested in the platform. But offline is just as good for a lot of things - and better for some.

Or, to put it even more simply: Technology exists to make things easier. If it isn’t doing that, then rethink what you’re using it for.

entry.title: Takeaways from the IT Leaders Summit

link.title: Takeaways from the IT Leaders Summit

entry.content:
Last week I went to Computing’s IT Leaders Summit. Amongst other things, we talked about managing IT Security, the rise of Generative Artificial Intelligence, and what’s going on with IT budgets. Here are some of the things I’ve taken away.

IT spending is up

This is driven by the higher cost of essential tech, and increase in the need for IT spending, and the rising cost of SaaS (Software as a Service) and Cloud products. (If all of those sound like they mean the same thing, welcome to IT budgeting 101.)

In one of the opening talks of the Summit, Computing’s John Leonard went through results of a survey the publication had conducted across the IT sector. Of the respondents, 50% reported an increase in real terms in the money they spent on IT compared to last year. Of this increase, the largest rises went to cloud infrastructure. Some organisations had reported rises of as much as 4x inflation for their licenses. While that was certainly at the higher end, the likes of Microsoft, Google, and Salesforce have or will be raising their prices by an average of 14% compared to 2022.

While actual spending is up, these are on things that individual companies don’t really have much control over. If you don’t want to pay the increase in license fees for your Microsoft 365 accounts, your other alternative is… Well you don’t really have one. At least, not one that doesn’t come with it’s own large costs to migrate. What this means is that the budgets that IT professionals have to play with when it comes to the “extra stuff” is greatly diminished. Companies are concerned about upcoming fixed costs - like what happens when your current software stack goes End Of Life and you’re forced to upgrade.

Strong cyber security is more important than ever

Traditional IT security is based on a very simple concept: here is a list of known viruses, bad people, and nefarious software. If you see it, delete it. That’s worked well enough for a while. But these days the problems aren’t confined to virus and spam emails. Modern hackers can leverage “safe” software - genuine applications that you have on your device right now - and twist their purpose.

In a talk on Zero Trust Security Measures, Threatlocker’s Seamus Lennon gave the example of a company which had been a victim of a ransomware attach using an email client, Windows Powershell, and the popular 7zip application. Blocking any of these apps is functionally impossible. You can’t run a company without your email client, and your Windows laptop can’t run without Powershell.

You can sort of mitigate for this in a “traditional” office setup, because your IT admin can stick a fancy firewall at the gates of your office and monitor everything that comes in and out. Except very few companies post-pandemic still operate in a way that makes this a failsafe. “The biggest challenge to network security,” says Lennon, “is that there is no network.” With the boom in home offices, remote working, and the average person now blurring the lines between personal and professional use of their office laptop, keeping devices safe in a world where ransomware attackers can use legitimate applications to cause damage is a IT security nightmare.

AI is… complicated

And I don’t mean technically. There are a lot of things I hadn’t considered about Artificial Intelligence. Did you know, for example, that the increase in access to AI makes people less likely to collaborate? Dan McMahon from Hymans Robertson made this point in a panel discussion. With AI tools cutting down on the grunt work needed for any given task, organisations are able to go further alone that they used to. Some are taking this as a sign that they don’t need to collaborate - it is much easier now to strike out on your own. I’m left to wonder, though it would be very hard to objectively measure this, whether progress in certain fields has actually slowed as a result of technology?

AI is likely to remain the plaything of the privileged.

AI is also likely to stay the purview of the privileged. Payment models for things like ChatGPT mean that the “free” version is several iterations behind what the paid plans provide. That’s not exactly new as a technology costing model. But Huseyin Seker from Birmingham City University made the point that as these costing models mature, those with resources are more likely to exponentially benefit from the technological gains that Artificial Intelligence provides.

Taking this thought a step further, much of generative AI “learns” from itself. By which I mean the exchanges are used to help modify and improve the platform. With barriers to access excluding certain groups, does that also mean we are more likely to create self-perpetuating echo-chambers of certain opinions?

And, spoiler alert, we’re about to talk more about payment for IT services…

Non-invasive tech is going to cost you

Recently, Meta announced they were exploring offering a paid tier for Instagram for EU users. This paid tier would mean they were not subject to targetted adverts on the platform. This is part of a drive by the EU to end the era of “if the service is free, then you’re the product”. On the face of it, this isn’t a bad idea. The reason we can flick through Instagram reels “for free” is because the data of what we look at, like, and share is worth a lot of money to Meta. Offering a paid tier allows you to still consume user-generated content that you like, but without having your data mined and sold.

My concern is that we’re going to enter an age where the ability to consume content safe from algorithmic influence is only going to be for those who can afford it. In the same way that those benefiting from - and therefore influencing the direction of - AI. Here though, my concern is less about how the platforms will be shaped by those with money. It is more about what happens to those who won’t or can’t pay. They will still be served those ads, and the ads will be more aggressive for it.

I talk a little more about how pervasive technology is in my blog about Technology and the Cult of Celebrity

Most people will experience online harm

Did you know that 62% of adults who access the internet have encountered online harm in the last week? Did you know that number goes up to 68% for 13-17 year olds? Chloe Colliver of Ofcom, talked through some of the research that lead to the creation of the Online Safety Bill - due to be passed into law in the coming weeks.

The average person in the UK spends a little over 4 hours online every day, and of that nearly an hour is spent just on Meta apps and websites (Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp, and Messenger). Other social media platforms, including Snap, X, and TikTok, also make up considerable amounts of time - especially for younger users. The Online Safety Bill is designed to protect UK Citizens from online harm, including illegal pornography, online trolling and other forms of verbal abuse, and certain types of internet fraud.

There are a number of legitimate reasons why someone might need to be anonymous online.

While a full discussion on the Bill is beyond the scope of this post, there are some things to note. It’s a very complicated document that can be interpreted in a number of ways - something that critics have been eager to point out. It also seems to demand the ability to decrypt secure messages, and calls into question how anonymous one can be on the internet. Clearly there are nefarious purposes for being untraceable online, but also there are a great many reasons someone might need to remain anonymous (tangentially related: this 2021 post from Anonyome Labs about the risk of removing online anonymity).

That said, you can’t argue with the numbers. With more young people accessing the internet more often, at a younger age, there certainly needs to be more thought put into making sure people are safe. As pricing models for everything from Generative AI to messaging apps evolve, different groups are going to be targeted for different reasons.

Check out the Centre for Countering Digital Hate, which (alongside being sued by Elon Musk) is celebrating its 4th anniversary.

Final thoughts

I continue to be a technology optimist. The benefits we can all get from advances are almost limitless. But it is just as important to remain aware of how fast moving tech can also be something to keep an eye on. We are continually putting more of ourselves online, conducting more of our business globally, and becoming more reliant on third parties to ensure our day-to-day lives run smoothly. There isn’t necessarily anything wrong with that, but make sure you keep yourself up-to-date.

If you want to chat about anything you’ve read here, do feel free to reach out to me on email, or via X (formerly know as Twitter), Mastodon, or LinkedIn.
entry.summary: Last week I went to Computing’s IT Leaders Summit. Amongst other things, we talked about managing IT Security, the rise of Generative Artificial Intelligence, and what’s going on with IT budgets. Here are some of the things I’ve taken away. IT spending is up This is driven by the higher cost of essential tech, and increase in the need for IT spending, and the rising cost of SaaS (Software as a Service) and Cloud products. (If all of those sound like they mean the same thing, welcome to IT budgeting 101.) In one of the opening talks of the Summit, Computing’s John Leonard went through results of a survey the publication had conducted across the IT sector. Of the respondents, 50% reported an increase in real terms in the money they spent on IT compared to last year. Of this increase, the largest rises went to cloud infrastructure. Some organisations had reported rises of as much as 4x inflation for their licenses. While that was certainly at the higher end, the likes of Microsoft, Google, and Salesforce have or will be raising their prices by an average of 14% compared to 2022. While actual spending is up, these are on things that individual companies don’t really have much control over. At least, not one that doesn’t come with it’s own large costs to migrate.
